December 2004

This report was prepared by H. Baxter, Pacific Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Timor-Leste  has made  considerable progress in economic and 
financial  management  since  independence  in  2002.  Implementation  of  the  National 
Development Plan (NDP) and road map is being achieved, and the Government is enhancing 
decision-making through the use of comprehensive sector analyses and the formulation of 
sector investment programs (SIPs), which identify investment opportunities for both Government 
and  development  partners.  Considerable  challenges  remain  in  this  area,  despite  the 
considerable achievements to date. 
 
2.  The  current  assistance  program  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  identifies 
capacity development in economic management as a priority focus area. ADB has provided 
assistance in this sector since 2001. Key technical assistance (TA) grants1 have supported the 
Government in economic and financial management. The Government has appreciated, in 
particular,  the  expertise  provided  by  the  petroleum  fiscal  adviser  to  the  Prime  Minister’s 
Department on the issue of Timor Sea revenues. The Ministry of Planning and Finance (MPF) 
has  received  valuable  assistance  for  the  development  of  SIPs  in  the  energy,  transport, 
communications, and water sectors; and in the overall management and coordination of the SIP 
exercise. Support to MPF to improve monitoring of NDP implementation includes the provision 
of better tools, and development of in-house skills and competency to assist line ministries in 
planning and delivery of their programs. A common recommendation emerging from these TAs 
is that additional support is required to entrench the capacity already developed in these key 
government units and to enable them to respond to the immediate and medium-term challenges 
facing the Government. 
 
3.  This TA2 will improve the Government’s capacity for economic and financial planning 
and  management  by  continuing  to  support  NDP  implementation  and  the  management  of 
petroleum revenues. 
 
4.  During the Country Programming Mission in March 2004, the Minister for Planning and 
Finance endorsed the TA. The Fact-Finding Mission fielded in September 2004 finalized TA 
design and discussed the rationale, objectives, scope, cost estimates, and implementation 
arrangements  with  MPF.  In  December  2004,  the  Government  agreed  to  the  TA.  The  TA 
framework is attached as Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  The  Government  is  striving  to  build  its  economy  and  develop  a  responsible  and 
responsive government with an efficient, effective and accountable civil service from the point of 
view of donor harmonization and alignment. Many development partners including ADB, World 
Bank, United Nations, and bilateral agencies of the governments of Australia, the European 
Union, Portugal, and United States, among others, are actively involved in supporting public 
sector management. Challenges exist in several areas, notably budget planning and allocation, 
budget execution, and expenditure control and accountability mechanisms. The withdrawal of 
international advisers has lent urgency to the development of a well-designed, sustainable

capacity-building program in financial management across government. The Government has 
asked  the  World  Bank  to  lead  development  partners  with  an  interest  in  public  financial 
management  to  jointly  support  the  development  of  an  integrated  and  long-term  financial 
management capacity-building Program. ADB supports the concept of a joint integrated initiative 
to ensure that the efforts of development partners are coherent from the point of view of donor 
harmonization and alignment. This initiative is still in the planning phase and ADB is monitoring 
the progress. 
 
6.  A number of key issues can and should be addressed now. The Government’s draft 
priorities  and  proposed  SIP  for  public  sector  management  identifies  the  critical  need  for 
strengthened planning processes and a more comprehensive budget framework for revenue 
capture and expenditure management. 
   
7.  Strengthened planning and monitoring.  The National Directorate for Planning and 
External Assistance Coordination (NDPEAC) in MPF is the lead unit responsible for overall 
supervision  of  the  Government's  planning  process,  including  oversight  of  the  agency-level 
annual action plans, the SIP exercise, and preparation of the next 5-year national development 
plan. It is continuing to develop and implement a comprehensive, government-wide information 
system to monitor NDP progress, and to provide a central repository of information on donor-
funded projects. Complementing its planning mandate, NDPEAC is also responsible for overall 
coordination of external assistance to Timor-Leste. NDPEAC has a demanding work program 
over the next 4 years, and the Government has requested ongoing support for its work. 
 
8.  In the immediate short term, the Government needs to finalize the SIP process before 
the next Timor-Leste and development partners meeting. For the process to be of value in the 
long term, however, the Government needs to mainstream this process as an integral part of the 
annual  budget  process.  For  this  to  happen,  NDPEAC  must  be  able  to  take  the  lead  in 
supporting all government agencies in their planning and monitoring of the programs for which 
they are responsible through the annual action plan processes. NDPEAC also must be able to 
optimize the utility of the systems and documentation for planning and monitoring. 
 
9.  Fiscal management. Petroleum revenues will be important to Timor-Leste’s economic 
development. International experience, however, indicates that natural resource riches can be a 
cause for concern. Timor-Leste has adopted prudent policies regarding the management of 
petroleum and has committed to transparent and accountable operations for the management 
and tax regime for the extraction of oil and gas, and the management of the financial savings via 
a petroleum fund. The United States Agency for International Development and ADB have given 
the Government considerable support. The Government has drafted a fiscal policy framework 
and a savings policy, and is considering a proposal for a petroleum fund. An extensive public 
consultation process is under way. The Council of Ministers will propose the draft legislation for 
the petroleum fund to the Parliament in early 2005. 
 
10.  Future developments in this area will need to include an assessment of the results of the 
consultation process and the incorporation of that feedback into the Government’s next steps. 
The  implementation  of  the  legislative  and  policy  framework  is  critical.  Sound  revenue 
forecasting is vital to the Government’s economic management and budget planning process 
and is of great interest to the development partner community. The Government will face 
several critical decisions in this area and will be relying on the best possible information to make 
sound decisions. The Government has indicated that continuing support is vital.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
11.  The  goal  of  the  TA  is  to  achieve  competent  public  administration  and  effective 
government. Its purpose is to improve government capacity for economic and financial planning 
and management. 
 
12.  Specific outputs will include (i) capacity development in implementing the NDP, including 
improving  tools  and  skills  for  planning,  monitoring  and  reporting  programs,  activities  and 
performance  at  agency  level;  and  (ii)  capacity  development  in  economic  and  financial 
management of petroleum and natural gas revenues. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  To develop capacity in implementing the NDP, consulting services will be provided to 
undertake the following activities: (i) support NDPEAC officials in implementing the SIP process 
to finalization for the 2005 Timor-Leste and Development Partners Meeting; (ii) prepare user 
guidelines  and  training  materials  for  implementation  of  the  Government's  reporting  and 
information management system (GRIMS); (iii) design, develop, and implement a train-the- 
trainer program for NDPEAC staff responsible for supporting line ministry focal points; and (iv) 
advise on preliminary preparations for next NDP. 
 
14.  To develop capacity in economic and financial management of petroleum and natural 
gas revenues, consulting services will be provided to undertake the following activities: (i) 
advise on the implementation of the proposed fiscal regime and gas valuation methodology for 
gas  projects;  (ii)  advise  on  fiscal,  economic,  and  financial  matters  affecting  Timor-Leste’s 
interests in oil and gas projects; (iii) advise on the regulatory and fiscal provisions for natural gas 
development in the Timor Sea; (iv) advise on possible fiscal frameworks for management of 
future petroleum revenues; (v) advise on revenue forecasts from the Timor Sea for budget and 
fiscal planning purposes, including the preparation of financial models of the main petroleum 
projects under consideration in the Joint Petroleum Development Area of the Timor Sea; (vi) 
participate in negotiations over petroleum matters with current and potential investors, or with 
other governments and international organizations; and (vii) promote awareness of petroleum 
fiscal  issues  among  government  personnel  in  Timor-Leste  and  development  of  skills  in 
petroleum economic matters for Timor-Leste officials. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $295,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $250,000 
and the balance of $45,000 will be provided by the Government through the provision of 
counterpart staff, support services, office facilities, and seed supplies. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB's TA funding program. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  MPF will be the Executing Agency. The TA will be implemented in close cooperation with 
the Office of the Prime Minister and the Timor Sea Office.

4 
17.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  24  months  beginning  1  February  2005,  and  is 
expected to be completed by 31 January 2007. 
 
18.  One international consultant will have expertise in public financial management and 
budget  planning,  and  demonstrated  capability  in  transferring  skills  and  knowledge.  The 
consultant  will  provide  2  person-months  of  input.  One  international  consultant  will  have 
expertise in fiscal management in the petroleum and gas industry, and provide 1.5 person-
months of input. Short-term consultants will be recruited based on areas identified when the 
capacity development program is developed, and will provide a total of 4 person-months of 
consulting services. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be 
engaged  by  ADB  on  an  individual  basis in  accordance with  its  Guidelines  on the  Use  of 
Consultants. The consultants will provide inception, progress, and final reports to ADB. 
 
19.  The results of the assistance will be disseminated throughout the government in Timor-
Leste and to key stakeholders including the country’s development partners. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Timor-Leste for Strengthening Financial Management Capacity, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Public Financial Management Specialist / Planning Specialist (international, 2 
person-months) 
 
1.  The Specialist will have expertise in public financial management and budget planning. 
 
2.  The specific responsibilities of the specialist include the following: 
 
(i)  support the Ministry of Planning and Finance in the implementation of the National 
Development Plan; 
(ii)  assist  the  Ministry  of  Planning  and  Finance  in  the  development  of  sector 
expenditure programs; 
(iii)  assist the Ministry of Planning and Finance in preparing for and conducting 
negotiations with development partners on possible investments; 
(iv)  identify knowledge and skill requirements of National Directorate for Planning and 
External Assistance Coordination staff and other gaps in capability and make 
recommendations and plans to develop appropriate capacity; and 
(v)  promote awareness of the sector expenditure program among government 
personnel and contribute to the development of knowledge and skills in the budget 
planning process. 
 
B.  Fiscal Management Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months) 
 
3.  The  Specialist  will  have  expertise  in  fiscal  management  in  the  petroleum  and  gas 
industry and other related areas. 
 
4.  The specific responsibilities of the specialist include the following: 
 
i)  advise on the implementation of the proposed fiscal regime and gas valuation 
methodology for gas projects; 
ii)  advise on fiscal, economic, and financial matters affecting Timor-Leste’s interests 
in oil and gas projects; 
iii)  advise on the fiscal implications for Timor-Leste in negotiations over territorial or 
jurisdiction arrangements in the Timor Sea; 
iv)  advise on the regulatory and fiscal provisions for natural gas development in the 
Timor Sea (including gas transportation); 
v)  Advise  on  possible  fiscal  frameworks  for  management  of  future  petroleum 
revenues; 
vi)  advise on revenue forecasts from the Timor Sea for budget and fiscal planning 
purposes, including the preparation of financial models of the main petroleum 
projects  under  consideration  in  the  Joint  Petroleum  Development  Area  of  the 
Timor Sea; 
vii)  participate, as required, in negotiations over petroleum matters with current and 
potential investors, or with other governments and international organizations; and

viii)  promote awareness of petroleum fiscal issues among government personnel in 
Timor-Leste and development of skills in petroleum economic matters for Timor-
Leste officials. 
 
C.  Short-Term Consultants (international, 4 person-months) 
 
5.  Short-term consultants or facilitators will be recruited based on areas identified when the 
capacity development program is developed. The detailed terms of reference and qualifications 
will also be determined during this stage. 
 
D.  Reporting Requirements 
 
6.  The  consultants  will  provide  inception,  progress,  and  final  reports  to  the  Asian 
Development Bank.
